questions.text: A 48 year old female patient presented with burning pain associated with fluid filled lesion over right shoulder. What will be diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Painful vesicles in grouped manner in dermatomal distribution is suggestive of Herpes zoster. (Option B)

Option D- Herpes simplex is not related to dermatomal distribution. usually present as vesicles or crust around lips and oral erosions. Or it can present as genital erosions.

Option A- Molluscum contagiosum present as asymptomatic white to skin colored umbilicated small papules.

Option C- Varicella/ Chicken pox present as fever with polymorphic lesions over erythematous base over trunk (Dew drop on rose petal appearance).

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 25.27

questions.text: A farmer presented with the following swelling on foot with discharging sinus. What diagnosis do you suspect?
questions.solution:
Madura foot also known as Mycetoma, an uncommon chronic infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues in tropical countries is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains --------(Choice A)

Option B- Chromoblastomycosis (Verrucous dermatitis)

Clinical feature : Rough warty, cauliflower like lesions over exposed (trauma prone) sites . MC on foot

Choice C- Sporotrichosis

The characteristic infection involves suppurating subcutaneous nodules that progress proximally along lymphatic channels (lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis).

Choice D- Pheohyphomycosis:

Clinical syndromes include invasive sinusitis, sometimes with bone necrosis, as well as subcutaneous nodules or abscesses, keratitis, lung masses, osteomyelitis, mycotic arthritis, endocarditis, brain abscess, and disseminated infection.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition,page number - 32.74

questions.text: A 12-year old male presented with asymptomatic erythematous scaly lesions over back. There was history of sore throat. There were collarette scales in erythematous lesions. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting.
  • Flu-like symptoms a few days before the rash appears. First lesion is characterised by a large circular or oval "herald patch", usually found on the chest, abdomen, or back.
  • The herald patch is followed by the development of smaller scaly oval red patches, resembling a Christmas tree, distributed mainly on the chest and back.
  • Collarette scale is characteristic sign in pityriasis rosea. With edge peripherally attached and lifted up near the centre of lesion.

Option B- Pityriasis rubra pilaris Scaly (Pityriasis), Pink to orange (Rubra), Follicular papules (pilaris), Grouped papules frequently coalesce to form large plaques, typically with distinct islands of normal skin and islands of normal skin are often studded with erythematous follicular scaly papules. Palm and sole are commonly involved with orange red waxy keratoderma.

Option C- Pityriasis versicolor is a superficial fungal infection. There are hypo or hyperpigmented mildly scaly macules over neck,upper chest, upper back.

Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur

On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'sphagetti and meatball appearance'

On woods lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Option D- Guttate psoriasis

It is a variant of psoriasis that is classically triggered by streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or perianal) and is more common in children and adolescents than adults.

Manifests as numerous, small, scattered papules and plaques. These are often referred to as "drop-like" and typically manifest as 2 to 6 mm papules.

Tag- Pityriasis rosea

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number:25.90

questions.text: A 26 year old male presented with single painless genital ulcer. On examination single well defined indurated ulcer was present. There was history of unprotected intercourse one month back. What is the next IOC?
questions.solution:
• Male patient having painless genital ulcer one month after unprotected intercourse suggest primary syphilis.
  • Primary chancre is hard-indurated, non tender, does not bleed on touch.
  • Incubation period - 9-90 days
  • Dark ground illumination is IOC for Primary
  • Blood investigations are negative in primary syphilis.

Option B- Gram stain is useful for diagnosis of chancroid. It shows School of fish appearance

Option C- HSV 2 Ab is useful for herpes genitalis

Option D- Giemsa stain is useful of donovanosis. It shows Macrophages with closed safety pin appearance called 'donovan body'.

Tag: Syphilis

Reference: Sexually Transmitted Diseases And HIV/AIDS By Vinod K. Sharma,2nd edition, Page number:250

questions.text: A patient presented with hypopigmented rash with satellite lesions as shown in the image. What will be the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image is a case of BT leprosy

Hypopigmented patch with satellite lesions are characteristic of BT leprosy

Option D- In TT leprosy there will be hypopigmented patch without satellite lesions

Option B- In BL leprosy there will be multiple lesions which tends to be symmetrical in presentation

Option C- In LL Leprosy there will be multiple lesions in symmetrical manner.

Tag: BT leprosy

Reference: IAL Textbook Of Leprosy By Bhushan Kumar, 2nd edition, page number:241

questions.text: What skin condition is characterized by the presence of coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp?
questions.solution:
• Etiological agent: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Lesions of erythrasma are asymptomatic, erythematous to hyperpigmented. Occurs in axilla, groin or inframammary area.

Colors on woods lamp:

  • Erythrasma- Coral red
  • Versicolor- Yellow
  • Tinea capitis(Microsporum sp.)- Blue-Green
  • Tinea capitis( T. schoenleinii)- Dull blue
  • Vitiligo- Chalky white

Option B, C and D do not show fluorescence on wood's lamp examination.

Tag: Erythrasma

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 26.40

questions.text: A 3 year old female presented with skin lesions as shown in the image. There was a history of diarrhea. Which mineral deficiency can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare disorder associated with zinc deficiency. It presents with the classic triad of:

  • Peri-acral and periorificial dermatitis
  • Diarrhoea
  • Alopecia

Option B- Iron deficiency leads to anemia

Option C- Vit C deficiency leads to scurvy

Option D- Vit A deficiency leads to xerosis, phrynoderma,xerophthalmia, night blindness

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 4th edition, Page number- 63.26

questions.text: 60 year old female presented with skin lesion over face since 5 years. Patient is farmer by occupation. What will be diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

  1. Etiological Factor:
    • Exposure to UV light, particularly UVB wavelengths.
    • In the case described, the patient is a farmer, which indicates prolonged sun exposure.
  2. Presentation:
    • BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule.
    • It often shows surface telangiectasia (small, visible blood vessels).
    • The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving it a rolled or rodent ulcer appearance.
  3. Common Sites:
    • face, particularly the nose, cheeks, forehead, nasolabial folds, and eyelids.
  4. Characteristic Histological Feature:
    • BCCs are characterized by islands or nests of basaloid cells.
    • These cells exhibit palisading at the periphery with a haphazard arrangement in the center of the nests.
  5. Option A: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):
    • SCC is the second most common skin cancer, caused by cumulative UV light exposure.
    • It often arises from precursor lesions called actinic keratoses.
    • Common areas include the face, neck, bald scalp, extensor forearms, dorsal hands, and shins.
    • Color varies from flesh-toned to erythematous with scale, crusting, ulceration, and hyperkeratosis.
  6. Option B: Keratoacanthoma:
    • A low-grade, rapidly growing tumor, typically 1 to 2 cm in size.
    • Features a dome-shaped appearance with a centralized keratinous plug.
  7. Option D: Melanoma:
    • A tumor resulting from malignant transformation of melanocytes.
    • The 4 major types of melanoma include:
      • Superficial Spreading Melanoma: Usually flat, may become irregular and elevated with variegated colors and peripheral notches.
      • Nodular Melanoma: Often blue-black but can lack pigment.
      • Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: Larger than 3 cm, flat, tan, with marked notching of borders, beginning as small freckle-like lesions.
      • Acral Lentiginous Melanoma: Appears on palms and soles as flat, tan or brown stains with irregular borders; subungual lesions may be brown or black with ulcerations in later stages.

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition.Page number-141.1

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with an itchy, flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules on the inner wrists and flexor surfaces of the forearms. The patient denies any recent medication changes. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Lichen planus-

  • 5 P's- Pruritic, polygonal , Plane (Flat topped), Purple, Papules
  • Common sites- Flexor aspect of forearms, Hand, Feet, Oral mucosa
  • Koebner phenomenon is seen in Lichen planus.
  • Oral lichen planus is Painless white streaks in a lacy pattern in oral mucosa.
  • Nail changes-
    • Pterygium (Classic nail finding);
    • Thinning of nail plate (Most common nail finding)

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number-37.16

questions.text: A 25 year old 7 month amenorrheic patient presented with genital lesions as shown in the image. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Papules with warty surface around genitals which is known as genital warts/ Condyloma acuminata

  • Condylomata acuminata caused by HPV
  • Two types of HPV virus
    • Low risk - 6,11
    • High risk - 16,18
  • Treatment:
    • Podophyllin toxin, Imiquimod, Cryotherapy, Radiofrequency fulguration
    • In Pregnancy- Cryotherapy. TCA (Trichloroacetic acid)

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 25.58

questions.text: What will be treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is the most efficacious treatment for severe acne(grade 4).

Isotretinoin is the only therapy that impacts on all of the major aetiological factors implicated in acne.

It results in a significant reduction in sebum production, influences comedogenesis, lowers surface and ductal P. acnes and has anti-inflammatory properties. A dose of 0.5-1.0 mg/kg/day dramatically reduces acne.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 90.38

questions.text: 8- A college student came with painful grouped vesicles over genitalia. What will be the next investigation you want to perform & what will be the finding?
questions.solution:
Herpes genitalis presents as painful grouped vesicles over genitals. For this, Tzanck smear would be the next investigation which shows tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

Option B: In chancroid, gram staining is done which shows gram positive organism in 'school of fish' pattern

Option C: In leprosy, SSS (SLit skin smear) shows Acid fast bacilli

Option D: Molluscum contagiosum biopsy shows handerson paterson bodies

Reference: Sexually Transmitted Diseases And HIV/AIDS By Vinod K. Sharma,2nd edition, Page number:415

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions on inner thighs and peri anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size. The histopathological appearance is shown in the image. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The image is showing histology of molluscum contagiosum

D. Molluscum Contagiosum (Correct Answer)

  • Description: Papule with central umbilication, including on inner thighs and peri-anal region.
  • Histology:
    • Cup shaped lesion with inverted lobules of hyperplastic squamous epithelium which expand into the underlying dermis.
    • Henderson-Paterson or molluscum bodies are large eosinophilic inclusion bodies within keratinocytes.

A. Trichostasis Spinulosa

  • Description: Small, papular lesions, usually on the back, arms, and legs.
  • Histology: Dilated hair follicles; no "Henderson-Paterson bodies."

B. Condyloma Acuminata

  • Description: Cauliflower-like warts in genital and peri-anal areas.
  • Histology: Koilocytes are enlarged epidermal cells with a clear cytoplasm and an eccentric, irregularly shaped, hyperchromatic nucleus;The koilocyte is pathognomonic for HPV infection.

C. Donovanosis

  • Description: Ulcerative lesions, often in the genital region.
  • Histology: Donovan bodies (intracellular bacteria in macrophages);

Reference: Fundamentals of pathology of skin, 4th edition, Page number-211

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair?
questions.solution:
This picture shows polarizing microscopy of hair with "tiger tail band" appearance, seen in trichothiodystrophy.

Trichothiodystrophy

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • Abnormal synthesis of sulphur containing aminoacid leads to deficiency of cysteine and methionine. Thus, hairs are rough and fragile resulting in Tiger tail appearance.
  • Clinically patient presents with diffuse sparseness and broken hair all over scalp since childhood.
  • It can be associated with_
    • PIBIDS
      • P- Photosensitivity
      • I- Ichthyosis
      • B- Brittle hair
      • I- Intellectual impairment
      • D- Decreased fertility
      • S- Short stature

Option B: Trichorrhexis invaginata

  • It is hair shaft disorder.
  • Hair shaft telescopes into itself along the shaft (invagination) “Ball and Socket” appearance
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata is pathognomonic of Netherton syndrome
  • Netherton syndrom consists triad of
    • Atopic dermatitis
    • Trichorrhexis invaginata
    • Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa (Double edged scales)

Option A: Trichorrhexis nodosa

  • It is a hair shaft defect with nodes in hair shaft

Option D: Monilethrix

  • It is a hair shaft defect with beaded appearance in hair shaft

Tag: Trichothiodystrophy

Reference: Rook's Textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Page number- 68.21

questions.text: A patient was taking steroids as treatment for plaque psoriasis and the medicine was abruptly withdrawn. He now presents with pustules on lesions, as shown in the image. What will be diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Pustular psoriasis is considered a variant of psoriasis vulgaris.
  • It is characterized by yellowish pustules on an erythematous base with a variety of clinical presentations and distribution patterns.
  • The pustules can be widespread or localized.
  • Pustular psoriasis is triggered by steroid withdrawal.
  • Subtypes:
    • Generalized:
      • Von-Zumbush type
      • Annular type
      • Pregnancy induced (Impetigo herpetiformis)
    • Localized
      • Localized pustular psoriasis of pals and soles
      • Acrodermatitis continua of hallopeu
  • Von Zumbusch type: Severe and acute form of psoriasis which starts with pustules which merge to form "lakes of pus" or "sheets of pus".
  • Impetigo herpetiformis is Von zumbusch in pregnancy. Systemic steroids are DOC for impetigo herpetiformis.
  • Treatment of Pustular psoriasis:
    • Acitretin, Cyclosporine, Methotrexate.
    • Biologics (TNF- alpha inhibitors)
  • Option B: Erythrodermic Psoriasis
    • >90% body surface area shows redness/inflammation or scaling.
  • Option C: Impetigo is a bacterial Infection caused by gram positive bacteria like streptococci or staphylococci. Common in pediatric age group.
  • Option D: Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis is drug reaction characterized by an acute onset of mainly small non-follicular pustules on an erythematous base.

Tag: Pustular psoriasis

Reference: Rook's textbook of dermatology, 9th edition. Page number:35.34
